The staff weren't as knowledgeable about the area as I am genuinely used to but they were pleasant enough. The main thing I did not like about the unit was the bathroom setup. Although It was very nice with the jacuzzi tub and double granite top vanities, it needed to have a seperation between the toilet/shower and sink/jacuzzi areas. The only mirrors in the unit were in the bathroom and the full length closet mirror in the bedroom. I was travelling with co-workers and we wasted a lot of time waiting for each other to finish their showers before being able to use the mirrors to do hair/makeup, etc. Again, not a deal breaker just an area for improvement. Overall I would definitely come back to Tahiti Village.

Reviews.Title: “2nd time at Tahiti Village”
Reviews.Author: mkb607
Reviews.Content: We are owners at the Tahiti Village & just spent out 2nd week there & I am looking forward the the 3rd. We were not bothered at all by the salespeople. When we checked in & were given our welcome package, they asked & I said I would let them know. We never heard another word from anyone. Each time we go to Vegas, we learn more about the city, same goes about the village. They do have a shuttle, but the city bus is close & you can also catch the Duce. We never rent a car & I am too cheap to take a cab except coming & going to the airport. You are away form the strip, but it is much more relaxing. Vegas is not really a relaxing place to visit, but there is a very nice pool that is open form 8am till 10 pm. There is also a hot tub that is open 24 hrs. I spend hours in the pool. Talked to some of the liveguards. They are very nice young people. Some are full time students & work several hours there. I got their thoughts on lots of the shows. I am looking forward to when the new section is open. It will have the lazy river. Denny's & Tahiti Joes are located on the same propert. I would be happy to answer any questions if I can. I did ready something in a review of a different resort about smoking. AT the Tahiti Village you are allowed to smoke in the room on the 6th floor. If you are a smoker, you need to ask. Some fo the rules the hotel or resorts are city rules, not just theirs. We did have a nice time & I will go back. I am an owner & will return instead of trade. Thanks Marilyn

Reviews.Title: “Okay -- Need to pay attention to the Details!”
Reviews.Author: heathersap
Reviews.Content: My husband and I booked a week with Tahiti Village as a trade with Interval. We did not arrive until the 4th night of our week as we didn't want to spend a full week in Vegas, however, we had to use a week before it expired. We are Marriott owners of Desert Ridge in Phoenix, however, their Vegas property was not available when we needed to go and Tahiti Village looked nice enough as I looked through the various availabilities online with Interval. However, we were left a bit dissapointed. If Tahiti Village wants to compete with the likes of Marriott, Hyatt, etc. they will need to make some changes. We felt as if they focused more on trucking in (and yes -- it was truly trucking -- I've never seen so many busses of people) would be "buyers" then those that were actually staying at the resort. Don't get me wrong, they were friendly enough, but the service we are used to just wasn't there and the accomodations, while supposedly new, were left in a bit of disrepair. The first night we were put into a smoking room without really realizing it, as it was after midnight by the time we arrived. We thought it smelled a bit off, but decided just to go to bed. We were woken by a very large cload of smoke and smell coming from the lock-off door (we were in the lock-off side)! We had booked a non-smoking room w/ a view -- we got the view, but not the non-smoking room. They didn't even ask at check in if this was okay. I suspect that most non-smokers would forgo the view for clean air -- we are certainly in this group! They were able to move us to a new room that morning at least. I had to bring my laptop with me for a bit of work and was irritated to learn that I would have to pay $9.99 for 24 hours -- serioulsy, how expensive is internet! Very rarely have we had to pay for internet in the last several years at hotels and never once at a timeshare. Seems like a pretty "cheap" way to make an extra buck -- not exactly an amenity if you have to pay for it! We noted in our 1st room that the baseboards were pretty beat up already and that most of the furnishings were also in pretty rough shape. Yes, that is pretty nick-picky, but for a new property, I'm afraid to see what it will look like in a couple years -- this has never been an issue w/ Marriott type propertys-- probably because the quality of their furnishings is nicer to begin with. The bathroom also had issues, specifically the shower / bathtub. The shower head leaked and the bathtub had a crack / hole in it that if left for any length of time would definitely invite water damage under the tub. I would think that if you were trying to sell timeshares, that you'd take better care of your facilities. We visitited Tahit Joe's for lunch and were also dissapointed there. We were left at the hostess stand for at least 15 minutes, and finally gave up and sat at the bar. The waitress there was nice enough, but too busy to much bother with us. We had to ask to finally get our lunch order taken, even though she had handed us menus (after we asked for those). When we finally received our order, at least it was tasty. However, they could certainly learn how to speed up their service and employ enough people to wait on the guests that are there. Again, nothing drastic, but its often the details that make great hotel lines, great. To end, no -- we would never stay there again due to the number of issues we faced: individually none were a big deal, but all together enough to deter us from staying there again. However, we can see where its mostly just a new property that needs to work out various kinks. If they want to compete with the larger properties and the more popular timeshares, they will need to pay closer attention to the details or risk being labeled as a low-end hotel / timeshare provider. A few nice points: Never once were we harrassed to attend a timeshare presentation (BIG PLUS to us) and also the location of the property. It is technically on the strip, however is still 3 miles to closest big name -- Mandalay Bay. This may be a negative to some, but it was nice to be away from the glitz/glam except when we wanted to be there. Also, as it is very close to the highway, were were able to get out of town quickly on Sunday morning.

Reviews.Title: “Salesman (plural)--Dont Take NO !!”
Reviews.Author: brucer1
Reviews.Content: We went thru the presentation before the hotel was completed but were completely turned-off by there style.We did pay extra $100 for a hotel upgrade on there offer.(which was fine) Unless you really enjoy the time-share idea and wish to invest beware of this"invitation". They have a very scripted presentation and interview by several salesman who put the screws to you.

Reviews.Title: “Great Place to Stay in Las Vegas - Ignore the Sales people!”
Reviews.Author: Terrijordan24
Reviews.Content: We arrived in Vegas on Wednesday May 14th and we are staying at the Tahiti Village Resort. I am a timeshare owner and traded one of my weeks to a two bedroom lock off I did this because this was what was available at the time. Day 1: We rented a car from the airport which is pretty simple from McCarren. All the rental cars are under one roof now so you take a white bus which has all the rental car names on it and are delivered to the car company. It's one big building and very easy to figure out. We rented from Budget since I am a fastbreak member there which means you fill out your information online so it saves you time at the car place. Just look for your name and find your car and drive away. That simple. If you are renting a car and going to TV when you leave the rental agency you take three rights and you are there. Simple. The last right you take is Las Vegas Blvd and TV is on your right hand side. My first impression was that it doesn't look as big as it said it was. It is on the strip, on one side is an empty lot which I guess they are expanding to and the other is a place called Manor hotel which looks kind of dumpy. Another reviewer had mentioned that if you call ahead and ask for a room overlooking the pool or the strip you won't end up looking at the motel. I did do this and was granted a room on the 6th floor (this is high as this particular building goes) and a view of the pool. Our room is 1612/1612A. Check in was simple we got here about 3:30 our room was ready. If you walk in the front door to your left is the timeshare people and concierge and to the right is the registration desk. They took a credit card number for incidentals but I have had this happen everywhere I stay so no biggie. We went to the concierge to pick up our welcome packet (this is where they get you to sign up) since I am an owner (not here but a timeshare owner in general) they did not press me to see their "owners tour" You do want to go to this desk though because this is where you get your maps and coupons and your goodie bag (razor, toothpaste, antacid, aspirin, sample shampoos etc.) if you don't like that stuff I guess you can skip it. They also give you the activites paper which has the goings on of the resort listed Saturday - Friday some of the things they offer are sightseeing tours (South Rim Grand Canyon for $100 pp, Lake Mead) Field trips to Red Rock Canyon which leaves every Mon, Weds & Fri at 12:30 for $2.00 pp and a Laughlin all day tour for $10.00 on Tuesdays. For kids they have cookie decorating, arts and crafts, candy treasure hunts, create a critter, make your own sundaes and they also do morning walks 3 days a week. Gas here is currently 3.69 a gallon which is about 30 cents cheaper then were I live in upstate NY. I wish I could bring that home! When we left the front office we had parked in the front of the building our room was located on the left side if you were facing the building so we had to drive around to get to the elevators. One thing that I did not like is the parking situation. We were only able to park in the undercover spots once or twice. There is limited parking I will take a picture of it so you can see but the cars line the fence, maybe 40 or so spots. They are covered because the heat is pretty bad here (88 yesterday and expecting triple digets by Monday) there was one spot to be had when we first checked in so we took it. It was a bit confusing at first on where to get into the building but I am not sure if it was me or the map. I just got off a 5 1/2 hour flight and was starving so it was probably me. Anyway we found the elevators - to get into the building during the day time hours the door just opens up (from the outside coming in) but we noticed last night while it was still light out that they do lock and you have to use your key to get in which is nice at least there is a little security keeping people from just walking in. The elevators are to your right and if you look to your left they are right there. There are two of them and they are the full size ones. It is a new building so they work and they are quick. We got to the 6th floor where there are signs posted as to which way to go as to your room number. Our keys worked on both of our unit doors with no problem. Ok now the room, since there are only two of us in this room we won't be using the lock off but I will describe that first. When you first walk in you are in the kitchenette /living room portion of the room. It is plenty big enough for 2 and possibly 4 if you like each other (ha) there is a 3 seat bar counter to eat on, pull out couch, chair, two end tables, closet and TV in this room along with your kitchen which has a half size fridge (no ice maker) full size sink, microwave, coffee maker, toaster and blender. It also has the plates, glasses and utensils. There is a small hallway which leads to the bathroom which has a regular bath/shower, sink and toilet. The bath and toilet are not private (there are no doors separating anthing it's all one room) At the end of the hall way is the bedroom which has two end tables, I think a king size bed and small tv. You can access the bathroom from the bedroom or the hallway (two doors). That is about it on the lock off. Both rooms are very clean I even looked for issues and did not find any. I am use to having the bigger room but would not be upset with a lock off here. The larger room is pretty much the same but well, larger. This kitchen has the full size fridge and stove with everything you need to cook. It is actually quite beautiful with the granite countertops and stainless steel appliances. It is large enough to do what ever you want in it. There are also three stools to eat at the breakfast bar which is where I sit now to type this. This is an open air room which means no walls separating the living room dining room, kitchen areas. There is a small table for four, a pull out couch, and end table, coffee table and entertainment center with a small tv. The washer/dryer are located in a closet off the kitchen. They are one unit (washer/dryer combined). They have computers for the tv and a dvd player. You can get the internet for 9.99 per day which you can use their keyboard/tv screen or bring your own laptop and plug into their plug which is located on the bottom of the entertainment center. They will provide a cord for you at the front desk for free if you do not have one and you need to bring it back to them or they will charge you. It worked fine for me. There is no free internet service at TV but I was told that the new building, that has yet to be built, will have it. There is a Denny's connected to the building which has free internet and that also works fine. There is a balcony off of the living room which has a small table with four chairs. Our room overlooks the pool and it is very pretty. The bedroom is off the DR portion which is also plenty large enough but could use another or a bigger dresser. The dresser where the large screen tv sits has 4 small drawers and one of them is used to house the DVD player. There is a king size bed and it is comfortable. There are two end tables each with a drawer and a full size closet with about 10 hangers. You can access the bathroom from the kitchen portion of the room or from the bedroom. There is a jacuzzi tub where the double sinks are and the toilet and the steam shower (note on the steam room/shower - I enjoyed it but it is very hot, becareful not to get burned by the steam nozzle, keep away from it when it is on because it will spit out hot drops of water now and then and they do hurt, the steam also creates a bit of a smell, I did not notice it the first time but I did on the 2nd and 3rd time, it didn't stop me from using it though) are in their own little room. Our first night on the town we went to eat at Terribles on Flamingo and Paradise. We had a buy one get one buffet coupon so we figured we would try it out. This casino is older the buffet was 9.99 so it only cost 5.00 pp the food was only ok but worth 5.00. I recommend using any coupons you get because it is worth it unless you have alot of money and like to just spend it. I am on the thrifty side. You do need a car to get anywhere around here since this timeshare is located way down at the end of the strip. You CAN NOT walk to any casinos from here (not the strip ones anyway) it is on a highway with no sidewalks for walking. Mandalay Bay is over a mile away. They do have a shuttle that runs to Town Square, Tropicana and Treasure Island. It runs from 9 am to 11:30 pm everyday except Fri/Sat when it runs till 2am. I will try to post a pic of the schedule. Day 2: Went to the pool which is very nice. The lazy river is not built yet but they do have it dug out (I overheard a salesmen say August). The main pool is pretty large and does have life guards on duty. You get your towels by the pool and there is hut for drinks ranging from 7-10 dollars. There is a hot tub which was pretty hot. The hot tub is open 24 hours, pool from 8-10pm. We had breakfast at Denny's the Grand Slam breakfast is 6.99 which gives you a choice of 4 items. It was not busy and the wifi works great there. For dinner we went to the Rio for the seafood buffet. The price is 40.00 pp but if you like seafood it is very good. They also have prime rib and an excellent selection of deserts. We went to Albertson's to get our market stuff. It's about 3 miles down Warm Springs Road it is a full service market. There are also a couple of CVS drugstores and the Las Vegas Outlet mall is on this street. Across the street and down toward the strip is a large outside shopping center called Towne Hall. It is brand new and has all of your designer places in it. Day 3: We went to eat at Carnigies Deli in the Mirage - the sandwiches were huge but $$. We were looking for a food court but the Mirage does not have one. We went to a show at Danny Gans theater (Jay Leno). We visited the weight room here at Tahiti, it is on the small size it has about 8 pieces of equipment and it does look newer. They also have a sauna. For lunch we went to Tahiti Joe's and we both had the steak andwiches. They were really good and our bill was $23.00. Well worth it. TV Has a little store attached where you can buy food (eggs, bacon etc) snacks, some clothing, pool stuff, jewerly etc. Things are a little pricey so if you can hit a market you might want to do that. There are ALOT of sales people here but we were never bothered. We were asked when we checked in and that was that. The bad reviews that this place has gotten is mostly from the sales pitch (free vacation that you are offered) If you take those out of Trip Advisors reviews this resort would probably move up to one of the best places to stay for a timeshare resort. Check out was pretty painless also. We asked the day before we left if we could get a late checkout and they told us no because Wednesdays were a busy check-in day. I was kind of mad but figured I would wait till the morning. In the morning we arranged it with the cleaning crew ourselves and got to check out about an hour later. They were fine with it and when we did get down to the front desk no one even questioned us. We stayed by the pool the rest of the day till our flight time. If this review sounds kind of funny I wrote it while it was happening in Las Vegas, then added to it after I arrived home so it might look kind of strange. I apoligize for that. I have more pictures that I will post on another entry - I guess you only allowed to put on 10.

Reviews.Title: “Fabulous”
Reviews.Author: Ninn4
Reviews.Content: Just go! Great time. Clean, big beautiful units. A grocery shuttle that leaves Monday and Thursday at 8 am. It drops you off, you get groceries and then it picks you up. Perfect. Starbucks int he same plaza. Walk 5 mins. south and there is a huge outlet mall. Take the shuttle to Town Square. Great shopping and restaurants, open air concerts too. We didn't get a car and used the shuttle every day. It was perfect. Go and get half price show tix the day of. Tahiti village does a red rock tour for $2, take it, it was fun and gets booked early. Loved the unit, no complaints, clean, new and gorgeous. they have raffles during the week, get a ticket and show up. I won $25 to use at the resort. It worked out nice. I would buy at Tahiti Village in a second. We are actually grand chateau owners on the strip but I would buy here for sure.

Reviews.Title: “Nice stay”
Reviews.Author: ac116
Reviews.Content: A family member of mine is an owner of a grand Tahitian suite time share and invited the rest of the family for Easter. The accomadations can be described as an apartment. The balconey with a pool view was a wonderful place to eat breakfast and for my cousin's infant to exclaim about the planes coming to and from the nearby airport. There was only one instance in the whole week where a plane disturbed the room's peace. The plasma TV is in the master bedroom, which seems odd. It would be better suited in the living room. Also be prepared to not be able to forget Alan Thick since he greets you every time you turn on the TV. The pool and hot tub are great but the pool closes at 9 sharp. The closest thing to a casino is the video poker at the bar in Tahiti Joes. Tahiti Joes has great food too. The only problem we has was getting two cribs. For the 1st two days one of the babies had to sleep in an empty suitcase. housekeeping only comes once while your there (midpoint of stay) and between guest stays. During their cleaning they put away the pull out couch and blankets and pillows. This was kind of annoying since i was sleeping there and had to remake it. Potential buyers led by salesmen swarm the hotel grounds during the day. Take the red rock canyon bus tour leaving the hotel, its a great deal. Also rent a car if you want to visit the strip. The shuttle is convienent but only stops at two hotels so its easier to rent a car and use free parking. Or take a cab if you plan on partying. You cant party here however, there is nowhere to do it.

Reviews.Title: “Buyer Beware”
Reviews.Author: rp17
Reviews.Content: I will start with it looks nice and the rooms are big, while starting to build more buildings and a much bigger pool. It's also way south of the strip. But...we went for the 3 night stay on them and took the tour. The people who work there or "salesman" as they might try to call themselves, were walking cliches. Our sales lady, while very nice and polite, had these huge fake orange nails, took a smoke break while I was in the bathroom for 1 minute, then stunk the rest of our conversation. We didn't say yes, so the other walking cliche 'finance manager' comes over and does his numbers on a pad of paper. Nothing there is in print; its pointing at magazines for half a second or some book. He was munching on his gum while talking in his black suit black t-shirt outfit talking about his hummer with his fake diamond encrusted rolex standing out. Cheesy cheesy cheesy! It's amazing how fast they want you to commit to dropping $25-48K after a small tour and a conversation. It's a numbers game for the people walking through the door- they don't care. I was told over 700 people per day! Just beware what you're getting into, do your research and be prepared.

Reviews.Title: “the math doesnt add up”
Reviews.Author: bluebullonagrnmeteor
Reviews.Content: My New Bride and I went to Las Vegas to get married. we called the Tahiti village 800 number and made arrangements for our stay. In 2007 we had went to their other facility off decator next to a Dennys...just up the street from the Orleans. At first we thought it was a hotel and was delighted in the setup and was interested in staying there this year (08). When we spoke to the counter help she told us about the concept and gave us a short tour. We called this year and went on the tour as she had suggested. Our tour guide this time was polite and professional; however when we were given the price after several inquires it was a bit beyond our current income. My current monthly payment is 1010.00 for 2000 SF. And their payment was roughly 750 per month. The guide kept pushing that we wouldnt have to spend more than 140-170 when we travelled compaired to the 400-600 we'd spend at a regular hotel; yet thats really deceptive because if this were the case we would have forked out almost a grand on a mortgage for a tahiti village certificate that essentally said we owned a time share only days before our trip....oh im sorry a "vacation ownership" or whatever title they are calling it this year. What boggles my mind is how i can own it if i dont really own anything but time at one of their resorts. We dont have an actual piece of property to call our own. For instance...should i get some time in the dog house i couldnt just go to my "vacation ownership" and have a place to stay. Id have to call and make arrangements and hope that i get a room with a view. So really what theyre selling is vacation time. And at the high interest rates we were quoted i can only imagine what the rate woulda been in the end if i had bad credit. When we inquired about play areas for our kids the tour guide said, "there is a play ground across the street." He was proud to point out the meager gym (honestly only because the development wasnt finished) and the beach like pool with a kids sand area with only one little blonde kid digging a hole (where were the parents by the way....and i dont mean the 5 life guards on duty). Now for anyone else with a five and 8 year old child you know that a sand box has a shorter entertainment life than a sand clock hour glass. In all honesty the concept and a good portion of the perks are great and we'd be interested in this when my retirement comes in the next few years. But given the treatment we recieved when we told the tour guide, the finance manager, and the marketing rep that this was not financially feasable; i'd be more inclined to just buy a property near the beach in santa monica to sneak off to for some quiet time. We must say that the Tahiti Joe's lounge and the food there was really good, the bartenders were swell and there is now a tiki mug from Tahiti joe's standing in my collection. I must thank Tahiti village for the hour of free gambling and the $100 in shell cards for the nice ride home with my lovely bride! By the way where is my $98 refund?

Reviews.Title: “Great place to stay, especially for families”
Reviews.Author: windychris1
Reviews.Content: This review is for the purposes of staying at TV as a hotel, not for a time share purchase. We stayed at TV for 3 nights. We got the 1500 sqft 2 bedroom suite for $200 a night through the Entertainment Book travel site. The configuration is two separate suites with a connecting door in the middle. One of the rooms was slightly bigger with a balcony. We were on the 4th floor overlooking the pool, partial view of the Las Vegas Strip, and could see planes landing at the airport. The suite had two full bedrooms, one full kitchen, one partial kitchen, one spa tub, and one steam shower. The spa tub and steam shower were in the bigger room. We could have lived in the place for a month in the way it was setup. The adults had their own bedrooms and the children slept on the pull out beds in the living rooms. Two families could easily be comfortable in this unit. The suite was very clean and nicely maintained. Everything worked fine. The bigger suite bed room had a huge flat panel in it. The rest of the TV’s were standard tube TV’s. The décor was an “island” type theme. It was quiet despite being so close to the airport and the jet landings and takeoffs were not an issue. The balcony was good sized and nice to sit on and check out the pool. The unit had a washer/dryer also. The resort was nicely maintained and showed little signs of wear. The pool area was incredible. They have a sandy beach area and wading pool type areas for the little ones. The kids had a great time at the pool. For a family with young children who want to spend a lot of time at the pool, this is the best feature about TV. The hot tub was very nice and big also. The hot tub is open 24 hrs. Sometimes the hot tub had too many kids especially at night. The pool does not have a lazy river or any water slides. TV is not within walking distance of any casinos. They do have free shuttles going to the strip all day and night so that helps. They do have a restaurant with video poker at the bar if you need to get your fix in without leaving the resort. Oddly enough they don’t have shuttles going to the closest casinos – The Silverton and South Pointe which are south on LV Blvd. If you are interested in shopping there is an outlet mall across the street. There are also some chain restaurants fairly close by. The resort has a Denny’s on site and a restaurant – Tahiti Joes. We ate at Tahiti Joes one night and the food was very good. The bar is nice with good drink specials and quite a lively “locals” scene into the morning hours. TV is a timeshare resort so there are quite a few people being taken on “tours” by the sales staff. We were not harassed to go on a tour by anyone from TV. When we got our “Welcome Packet” from the concierge they asked if we wanted free show tickets if we would take a tour. We declined and it was no problem. I believe the concierge desk has access to half price show tickets similar to locations around Las Vegas. There is construction going on at TV – they are building a new addition to the resort. It can be a little noisy, but nothing too disruptive. The new addition is massive – 6 stories. The building in question looks to be finished with the major construction. They did have a giant crane operating when we were there – installing huge palm trees. If you want the “true” Las Vegas strip experience, then this is not the place as the location is away from the Strip. If you are looking for a casual, relaxed environment away from the chaos of the Strip, then TV would be a good choice. If you are a family looking for a nice, relaxing place to stay, with a great pool, then TV would also be a great pick. Just a few thoughts if you are planning to stay at TV. An outside upper floor room (4th floor or higher) on the north side of the resort will have a direct view of the Las Vegas strip – which at night is spectacular and the planes landing and taking off at the airport will be right in front of you. There is nothing in front of this part of the resort (because of the airport) and no street noise. It may be louder because of the airport, but the view of the Strip is spectacular. If that is not available then go with a room facing the pool area as the anything else will be overlooking the parking lot or Las Vegas Blvd. There is one minor negative about the location of TV. Next door to TV is the Manor Hotel. This hotel is low budget place with extended stay type rooms. There are some sketchy people around this hotel. Lot’s of hanging around on the balconies, drinking beer, smoking, some screaming, etc. Basically the entire outside south part of the resort faces the Manor Hotel. I would avoid any room that faces toward this place. A few other minor issues in the suite were the lack of adequate drawer space for clothes and the beds could have of higher quality -- better mattresses, have matress pads, etc. No big deal but some people are picky about stuff like this. Overall, I would highly recommend TV if you have a family or just want to avoid the madness of the Strip. It is a great value and a nice place to stay.

Reviews.Title: “Wonderful”
Reviews.Author: PAKat
Reviews.Content: I can't say enough good things about Tahiti Village. The personnel were so helpful, and we never encountered any pushy sales people. The rooms are beautiful and clean. The courtesy van ran like clock work.

Reviews.Title: “Class Act”
Reviews.Author: Blokzijl
Reviews.Content: No need to duplicate previous reviews regarding the amenities and the sales pitch, though must note that as an owner or exchange client the sales pitch is more subtle-initially. You are assigned a personal concierge, who only after he tells you he can get 1/2 price and free tickets for you, requests a $20 deposit to hold your place at the "owners update." We lucked out, our salesman and financial managers were not pushy. When we travel we take our food, pillows etc. with us, so frustrating not to be able to locate a luggage cart, had to use a garbage cart?!? Interestingly the flat screen TV is in the bedroom where we only slept; issue with others also apparently so this is being changed. As an exchange, we apparently lucked out on being assigned a Bora unit; I had done my research on Travel Advisor so was prepared to know what to look for. Thank you.

Reviews.Title: “Good place to stay”
Reviews.Author: SunnyCali
Reviews.Content: Booked this thru expedia.This place is great to stay at if you dont mind no casino and no smoking. The check in was great and had no preasure to attend the sales pitch. I just told them no thank you. The rates were better then the prices at a hotel. I got the big room with the kitchen ,living room and bedroom for $100.00 a night you couldnt get a decent regular room for that rate. There is no room service but that doesnt botherme, I would just call for extra towels or take them from the maids cart. They have a shuttle that takes you to 2 differnt places on the strip, twice per hour. Save money on taxi there. I am staying here again, worth the money and the noise from the airport doesnt even bother you.

Reviews.Title: “Love It! Will be back!”
Reviews.Author: HOWELLTSG
Reviews.Content: My husband and I are new owners at the Tahiti Village. After carefully considering a time share in Myrtle Beach and then going there and seeing how much more value we could get. It was a no brainer. Everyone was very considerate there and would do anything for you. We rode in the limo a couple of times to places we wanted to go. Not only does staying here increase your chances of getting places outside of Vegas, you also get free transportation to places all along the strip. Before going here, I did not think that I would ever want to go back to Vegas, but now we will be going at least once a year. (If you want to rent a room, let me know) I am really sad to read the reviews that others have posted. Being a Marketing director myself, I understand that it is tough to get a sale in different situation, but being persistant and pushy isn't always the answer.

Reviews.Title: “pushy pushy pushy”
Reviews.Author: jesuser
Reviews.Content: Me and my wife and my 4 year old son were staying at Circus Circus we were given this opp to get free tickets if we would give then 90 minutes of our time. So we went they said about 20 times they weren't pushy. The speaker siad our sales rep said it the manager sales rep said it over and over. The starting price was 47,000 and when we said we were not interested the manager came over and started lowering some number's. Again we said no can we have our free stuff they said sure but needed another one of they're managers to make sure they 'er sales rep's were nice so we waited 10 min. WE he finally came over he lowered it again when we said no the sale's rep told us she thought we were going to buy in an angry voice and walked of. SO THEY'LL BE NICE AS LONG AS THEY THINK UR BUYINNG FEB 18 2008

Reviews.Title: “WOW”
Reviews.Author: cookieny
Reviews.Content: We booked a two bedroom , 2 bathroom suite. The suite was Huge (1500 sq feet)! The granite kitchen was lovely and well equiped. The pool area was set up like a tropical paradise. It was very clean and towels were provided so there was no need to bring them from the room. We enjoyed the fact that it was a no smoking facility and it was quite compared to the bustle of the casinoed facilities. We would defintiely stay here again.

Reviews.Title: “No”
Reviews.Author: tttttttttttth
Reviews.Content: It was ratty th pool had throw-up in it and we had to wait for our room becuse somebody got "held up" the hotel didn't even hurry them the rest of my trip was great I won bingo and got 2,000$ that was great but the hotel stinked

Reviews.Title: “Loved it, loved it, loved it!”
Reviews.Author: ravhur
Reviews.Content: We spent 8 nights here from the 11th to the 19th of January and it was the best accommodation we had in our whole trip to the States. Everything was new and shining, the size of the room was great and there was the added advantage of having a full kitchen and a washer/dryer combo. We got a good rate from Expedia and were not asked, even once, to attend a timeshare presentation. The shuttle was a bonus and ran on time. Obviously we were there at a time that was not busy as we didn't have a problem with waiting for it. Having Tahiti Joe restaurant across the parking lot was great as they delivered to our room for a small charge and we enjoyed the food. We asked for a quiet room and I have to say that they really delivered as we didn't hear anyone else in all the time we were there. We were far enough away from the strip to forget we were in Vegas when we wanted and close enough to drive there in no time at all. The factory outlet was fantastic shopping and just down the driveway. All in all, this was excellent value for money and a top class resort.

Reviews.Title: “Happy Tahiti Village Owners”
Reviews.Author: artiststylist
Reviews.Content: my wife and I purchased a Bora Bora property in 2004, back when Tahiti Village was a dirt lot. We used it for the first time Jan 17th through the 20, for our 10 year anniversary, and I must say we had a great time! The rooms were spacious, with patio and steam sauna, nice stainless steel kitchen, great services, including work out room,massage, store, and tahiti Joe's resturant! The shuttle runs every 30 minutes to the shopping center and to the strip. What REALLY stood out was the concierge service, we worked with Mikey, he was awesome, helpful, upbeat, knowledgable! He got us great tix to Cirque de Soliel; it was a bit cold for the pool, though. Most of all we are happy to see our investment triple since e purchased it! Highly recommended!

Reviews.Title: “Impressive Place - Great Time”
Reviews.Author: ebdbmcc
Reviews.Content: I am a tahiti Village timeshare owner and stayed for the first time in September, 2007. I was a little nervous with some negative reviews out there but once we stepped foot into tahiti village, all of that nervousness had disappeared. Front desk check-in was simple and we were assigned a room right off the bat. The baggage claim handlers were there anxious to help us to our room. We stayed on the first floor, facing the pool. The rooms were absolutely beautiful. Very clean, and all furniture and appliances looked brand new! The concierge desk was extremely helpful in getting us reservations to restaurants and shows on the strip. There is a shuttle that brings you to and from the strip and are very timely. This is a great place to stay and I highly recommend this to families and couples. I even upgraded my unit!. By the way, if anyone is interested in buying, please contact me because I am a multi-unit owner and I am considering selling a unit. So, before you buy from the resort, I am considering selling thousands of dollars below resort price. Send me an e-mail for more information.

Reviews.Title: “Very comfortable -- nice bed and bed sheet!”
Reviews.Author: KeenTiger
Reviews.Content: Pros: 1. Everything is new! Love the new and updated facilities 2. King size bed with nice bed and soft bed sheet, slept very well 3. Full granite kitchen with stainless stell appliances, such a luxury kitchen experience... it has all the basic cookwares and bowls/plates/knife 4. Big plasma TV in bedroom, Jacuzzi and steam shower in bathroom 5. 24/7 onsite Dennys, onsite snack bar/grocery for simple grocery like milk/butter/bread/jams (I cooked breakfast for my hubby every morning!) 6. Las Vegas outlet center is walking distance 7. Shuttle services to Tropicana, TI every 30mins, even have groceries shuttle at the morning! 8. Nice Sand swimming pool and jacuzzi, and gym too (I saw it but didn't have time to use it) 9. Laudry in the unit, never worry about run out of clothes to wear at vacation ;) they even provide detergent Cons: 1. not daily room services, only get 1 room services for 1 week stay (I personally don't mind to use the same towels for 3~4 days) 2. it's 2 miles south of Mandaly Bay, not walking distance to strip, but we have rental car and we took shuttle sometimes (run every 30mins) so it doesn't bother us much 3. Not all parking space are cover parking Overall: We enjoy tahiti village a lot, especially the nice bed/bed sheet and very thick window curtain that let us gamble/do stuff at night time and sleep til 3pm at day time... Definitely will try again. Oh... we rent this place from a friend who has timeshare so we didn't have to suffer the timeshare sales speech that some review mentioned. To us, it's just like any other hotel stay. Will definitely come back!

Reviews.Title: “FREE 4 day 3 night Vacation Package - Good Experience for us.”
Reviews.Author: scarlett329
Reviews.Content: My husband called in for this free vacation offer when he heard the advertisement on the radio by Tanya Roberts. He did not realize we had to sit through a possible horrible sales experience. After reading some of the bad reviews is was begging him to try and cancel but he said let's give it a try. Well, I'm glad we stuck it out. I know some of you had a bad experience but for us it was fabulous. First of all let me say, that we followed all the rules. We are married and had 2 forms of identity with us. We lucked out all the way around. The hotel they put us at was the Las Vega Renaissance which is a Marriott property. If you look at it online, you will see that it is a fabulous hotel, clean, new, contemporary, friendly and quiet (non-gaming), which was perfect for us. It was off the stip and located by the Las Vegas Hilton/Convention Center, again, okay by us. We checked in with the Tahiti Village gal at the desk and all went smoothly. She gave us all the coupons and gifts that were promised. The next day, the very nice complimentary shuttle took us to the Village. Again, we must have gotten lucky by getting the sales rep that we did, but after we explained that we really didn't do much travelling and that we were basically only there for the free trip, he said "well this probably isn't for you, but let me just continue my presentation and show you around because it's my job to do so". And that's all he did. Again we must have gotten lucky because even when his boss came by and lowered the price of the timeshare and we told him we weren't in a financia position to purchase he said okay and left us alone. Too easy. I was relieved. We got out of there with no hassles and still had another day to enjoy ourselves. Our sales rep Sam, took us downstairs where they had our deposit credit waiting and we were on our way. Our bill at the Renaissance hotel was ZERO. There had been a $50 per day deposit put on there also but was credited upon our check out. From what we saw, T.V. was very nice and if we were in a position to travel more we may have even bought. There were giving 12 weeks of timeshares away at different places for a low cost per week for life and other prizes like free timeshares weeks in Europe etc. But that didn't include airfare or incidentals, so I'm sure few people would even take advantage of the freebies. The condos were very very nice. But a word of caution, I wouldn't sign anything without knowing ALL the details of exactly what you're buying. So for us it was great, for others I see it was not so great. Good luck, Hope this review helps. 3 nights at the nice hotel we stayed at probably cost $600, we stayed for free. 1 more tip if you do go, we had the shuttle drop us off at the Riveria so that we could redeem our Comedy Show coupon and then get our ticket for the show at the ticket booth.

Reviews.Title: “"Worth it"”
Reviews.Author: MandaF
Reviews.Content: We found our rooms on expedia for, what I though was excellent, only $85 a night. Check in was at 4:00 pm, we had arrived around 1:00 pm and had no problem getting a early check in. The couple we were traveling with had reserved the larger suite which is connected buy a lock-off door to our smaller Moorea suite. They were able to put our rooms next to each other no problem. When we got to the rooms, our room had the most foul sewage smell ever, but within 15 min. of calling the front desk, a bellman had brought us keys to our new rooms exactly one floor up. Those rooms were just fine. That was the only glitch of the whole trip. Everything was very neat and clean. Lots of space. Our rooms were handicap accessible, meaning there was no bath tub, but we liked that. Shuttle was very convenient, drops you at Tropicana, Treasure Island, and Riveria. Pool area is great, but there is only one hot tub and it always had someone in it. The pool closes early at 10:00 pm. As for the people selling the time share. we were never bothered when at the hotel itself, but beware, they have sales people everywhere on the strip!! Those are the people who give this place a bad name. It's a littlebit of an over kill. And for all the people who are pissed that they were foolish enough to get suckered into the sales pitch. Get over it! Something for nothing isn't ever free. You wasted our own time being gullable. Just tell them no thanks and get on with our vacation.

Reviews.Title: “Just say not to the sales pitch”
Reviews.Author: FussyTravels
Reviews.Content: We stayed one week through our timeshare exchange program. It was a great spot - close enough to the strip, but far enough to get away. The suite was beautiful, just as pictured. Very clean & new with granite counters & stainless appliances. Grounds kept very clean, the pool was lovely. Shuttle to the strip every 1/2 hour was very handy. Just say "not interested" to the fairly heavy timeshare sales pitch & they will leave you alone. Highly recommend this hotel.

Reviews.Title: “Mai Tai, Roa Ae!”
Reviews.Author: tikinaut
Reviews.Content: My wife and I were very pleased with our stay at Tahiti Village. We booked our room through hotels.com ($85 per night) and were pleasantly surprised with the accommodations. The room was very clean and comfortable. Staff was helpful and courteous. There was no pressure put on us to purchase a timeshare. The pool is large and there is plenty of room for sunbathing. There is a Denny's restaurant adjacent to the hotel as well as a new place called "Tahiti Joe's" which is a Tiki bar themed restaurant. (Try their ribs. They are out of this world!) The hotel is about two miles from the main part of the Strip. There is a complimentary shuttle that will drop you off at either Tropicana or The Riviera every half hour. Keep in mind that Tahiti Village is a relatively new place, so they are still working out some of the kinks. When we were there they were having some problems with key cards not working in the pool gates. The only other minor complaint I had was the hotel's proximity to the airport. There are jets taking off overhead continuously. Somewhat loud, but tolerable. We would stay here again. I'd give it a B+

Reviews.Title: “Beautiful Place”
Reviews.Author: Shazzygirl11
Reviews.Content: Beautiful Place to stay. There were 6 of us, and we had a good time. Just 2 mins away from the strip. Was easy to catch the hotel shuttle to the strip otherwise getting a cab was not a problem either. Denny's was right next door for a midnight or early morning crave. The rooms were clean, complete with extra towels if needed. The view outside was awesome, felt like we were in Tahiti. We ended up cooking in the fully equiped kitchen. We had a good time. We will definetly stay here again. Planning another trip already. :)

Reviews.Title: “Terrible Experience!!!”
Reviews.Author: DHR
Reviews.Content: Reserved well in advance and called the day before to make sure reservations were solid, only to be told when arriving that a "GLITCH" made our rooms unavailable. The staff was inept and the wait was very long while they rerouted us to a "sister' property. We missed our show that night because of the horrendously long process (We were only in Vegas 1 night). The property they sent us to was decrepit and somewhat scary & lacked the number of beds we had reserved at Tahiti Village. We booked thru Hotels.com and they were completely unhelpful in resolving the problem with the hotel. I had to spend several hours a day of my vacation in California talking to different reps before they would even agree to a price adjustment that would be equal to the rate for the substandard lodging we stayed in. They said to wait 30 days for the credit to be posted.....it's been 2 1/2 months later and I've received no credit. DON"T book thru hotels.com - they'll leave you high & dry if there's a problem. And... DON'T count on a previously booked reservation at Tahiti Village!

Reviews.Title: “Great Resort”
Reviews.Author: cinleer
Reviews.Content: My husband and I purchased a timeshare at Tahiti Village before they even broke ground, and we are please to say that we have no regrets. We just returned from 5 days at the resort and, as usual, had a wonderful time. We have never had any issues with any of the resort personnel, and we really appreciate that they have lifeguards on duty at the pool. They are still going through construction, and even though our room was on the very end of tower 2, closest room to the construction, I was only bothered by the beeping of a truck in reverse on our last morning there. The check-out time is, in my opinion, ridiculously early at 10am, but if you call to the front desk you can request a late check-out. If you plan on seeing Vegas, I recommend getting a rental car, as the shuttle isn't always the most convenient means of seeing the sights. We always rebt a car, and I have no problem tipping the valet $2 at any of the casino's we visit. The new shopping mall is supposed to open soon, and rumor has it that there is a casino going in across the street. I think the only negative thing I have to say is that the free continental breakfast at Tahiti Joe's is a waste of time, seeing as it is only muffins, coffe and juice. Hit the grocery store down the road instead and get some toaster waffles. Lastly, if the large casino's aren't really a draw for you, or you are looking for lower ($5) table minimum's, I recommend going to the Silverton or the Southpoint, both of which are just south of Tahiti Village. The Silverton is the local's favorite casino, and we found all of our dealers very eager to help us, especially when we decided to learn craps. The Southpoint has a great staff, and we have found our favorite blackjack dealer there on both of our last two trips.

Reviews.Title: “Timeshare Owners Beware”
Reviews.Author: CreativeSmiles
Reviews.Content: The facility is great, large pool and Denny's restaurant in one of their buildings. Stayed one night as stopover on my way to Utah. On my way back, I attempted to check-in again to experience front desk staff are untrained to give best services to timeshare owners. My experience was when I got to the front desk at Tahiti to book a room from any of Consolidated Resorts properties in Las Vegas (Club de Sol Leil, Tahit and Tahiti Village) the front desk said I they have two Moorea units at Tahiti Village (where I own a timeshare), I was glad because it was a last minute thing because of a stop over from Utah to Los Angeles. I drove to the hotel and called on my way out of the parking lot to confirm, to find out that they gave the two rooms to someone else waiting at the lobby. Not even 5 minutes. The desk people are not trained to give VIP treatments to timeshare owners. They could have booked me immediately on my way out to Tahiti Village.

Reviews.Title: “Great Vacation”
Reviews.Author: jayla06
Reviews.Content: My Husband and I stayed at the Tahiti Village on September 7,2007 thru September 14, 2007. We arrived around 9:30 PM. Check in was fast and courteous. We were told our room was in the 2nd building on the third floor. The only problem was, we could not find the building. The key would not open the door of what we thought was building two. After a couple of go rounds, we went back to get better directions. We found that it was a certain way you had to put your key in the key pad. That was why we could not get in the building. There was no one to help us with our luggage but we manage to get it to our rooms ourselves. The Bora Bora room was wonderful. We had a view of the pool and my husband used the balcony every morning to enjoy his cup of brew and every evening to relax before bed,with that breath taking view of an island in the eastern pacific. I had read the reviews and was ready for the salespeople to rush at us. No such luck! When ever you passed them, they only said"Good Morning" or "Hello". The water was so hot, you could boil a hot dog until Thursday morning. I did have to take a cold shower. My husband told the staff and by that evening when we returned the water was quite comfortable. Speaking of the Staff, I was ready for the staff to be rude to us. Again, no such luck! I was impressed by the staff's knowlege to remember names. Everyday, they called my husband by his last name in speaking to him. The concierge desk, helped me obtain show tickets at a discount price. The staff sent a basket to our room. That was a surprise. Maybe that old saying "treat others as you would like to be treated ", still holds true. We went on the red rock canyon tour given by the hotel for only $2.00 per person. I could not believe for the price of a gallon of gas, we got a bus trip and sightseeing tour of the canyon. Having your linens changed in the middle of the week was a added touch. We ate Tahiti Joes ,once and had drinks and Nachos on another evening. Denny's, which is next door was more enjoyable for us. If you show them you room key, you get a discount on your meals. Please read the reviews and remember your vacations is what you make it.

Reviews.Title: “Good Hotel”
Reviews.Author: cecily
Reviews.Content: Overall it was a pleasant 7 day vcation at Tahiti Village. Don't believe when the reviews say.. that the timeshare people harrass you. When you are actually staying there... they dont mess with you. It is very peaceful, it actually felt like I was at a resort in mexico. The people that write the bad reveiws about the timeshare people harrssing them are the ones that are stupid enough to get dooped from the strip anways, and wanted something for free. I wont lie... I've done it to get free stuff but it has nothing to do with the hotel experience and the property... they are outside sales people. lol!!! If you want to stay at a nice relaxing hotel, this is the place. You can Vegas at your finger tips or leave it behind you. The pool was nice, hotel was immaculate. Bathrrooms were awesome!The shuttle service was great, (every 1/2 hour believe it or not) they give you free water and you take as many bottles as you like. The only thing I didnt like was that they only cleaned every 4 days, and when your on vacation and sharing a 2 bedroom suite with 5 other people. It can get messy, plus you don't really want to have to clean on your vacation either right? Also the concierege desk did not know anything about anything..no shows.. didn't know about nightlcubs etc. and they stop working at 5pm.

Reviews.Title: “Great Experience despite reviews”
Reviews.Author: nicholefecteau
Reviews.Content: My husband and I stayed at the Tahiti Village from Sept. 7-14, 2007. We arrived on a Friday a few hours before the check-in time (which is 4:00pm), expecting to drop off our luggage and hang around until a room was ready. The girls at the Registration Desk were great- getting us right into a quiet room on the 6th floor with a view of the strip. We were bombarded immediately by the woman across the way telling us to get our welcome packet. The packet was actually quite helpful. We politely told them we were not interested in seeing their "presentation," took our packet- and coupons, and headed to our room. (We were never bothered again by the salespeople or "welcome" desk people.) The Bora-Bora suite (1609) was perfect- large and clean. The kitchen was fully stocked, including a 12 cup Cuisinart coffee maker (a few packets of coffee were provided although we brought our own), toaster, and a blender. Every pot, pan, dish and utensil we could have wanted was there. There were lots of glasses- wine glasses too. Housekeeping also provided some dishwashing soap, dishwasher tablets, and laundry soap. We enjoyed the steam shower- which was perfect after a dry day in the desert- and jacuzzi. Both worked perfectly and were very relaxing. The balcony was much larger than I expected. There was lots of room- it was great. We used the Strip shuttle a few times. It was always on time at each stop. There is a cooler full of cold bottled water that you are free to take. We tipped the driver on the return trip to the resort. There were two instances where we didn't have hot water for a shower in the morning (Thursday and Friday). I read about that in another post so I expected it. In addition to the hot water issue, I also read about noise from construction and the airport. We never heard either. There were planes landing and taking off directly over the resort but once we shut the door we never heard them. The only bothersome noise was from the people below us running the water (filling up the jacuzzi or taking a shower.) While annoying, it wasn't unbearable. I understand people had trouble with the washer/dryer but we had no need to use the dryer at all. Each morning we did our laundry and put it out on the balcony to dry. It was refreshing not having to do all of that laundry when we got home! The pool area was well-staffed. Although there are signs that say no outside food/drink allowed we saw plenty of people bringing drinks with no trouble at all. One group even had a cooler and a bottle of Malibu! The lifeguards were plentiful. We never had a problem getting chairs- there were plenty. The Tiki Bar at the pool had odd hours. I am not sure what time it opened, but it closed by 4:00pm each day and the drinks were very overpriced. If you must buy a drink, hit the gift shop and grab something there for half the price. My husband used the fitness room a few times and liked the Universal machine. The salesmen give tours all day long, and they always go by the fitness room so be prepared- especially if you like the treadmill- which is right by the door. We used the Sauna as well. That was very nice and relaxing. It is big- we had 4 people comfortably in it. Tahiti Joe's was good. We split a plate of nachos- which was big enough to fill both of us. Something strange was that the "bar" part and "restaurant" part are owned by 2 different companies- so a separate waittress has to come out and take your drink order. You have to pay for your drink separately from your food. Not a huge inconvenience, just a little weird. The gift shop was well stocked- items we saw included- wine, beer, bread, breakfast food, milk, ice cream, gifts, sunblock, pool toys, etc. On the day we checked out (check out is 10am), we weren't flying out until 9:00pm. The girls at the Registration Desk gave us a pool key good for the entire day. That was nice- we were able to spend the day on the strip and then relax there before our flight. We checked our baggage and picked it up before we left. The taxi taking us to the airport took a while to get to the resort. Call at least 1/2 hour before you need it. All in all, we LOVED Tahiti Village. I was VERY skeptical after reading the reviews but would return in a heartbeat.

Reviews.Title: “No hotel is perfect...”
Reviews.Author: Paul07UK
Reviews.Content: My wife and I have just returned from spending 7 nights at Tahiti Village and despite a lot of negative reviews on here, we found the hotel a really pleasant place to stay and relax. We were very impressed with the quality and furnishings of our room (Bora Bora), and loved the large bathroom and jacuzzi. The kitchen had everything you need (including a wine bottle opener and ice maker in the freezer), and we especially liked the large LCD TV in the bedroom with DVD player. The regular half hour shuttle to the strip was really useful, and the free chilled water whenever you got on and off the bus was a nice touch. It was a shame you had to pay $9.99 for internet access when so many hotels in America offer it for free, and the service to fix problems in the room wasn't great either as we had to hang around for engineers to arrive. There was a negative review about Tahiti Joe's service and food which I don't agree with because we found the service excellent and the food really nice for what it was (we went there twice when too lazy to head back out to the strip) - I guess it just depends on the day really.

Reviews.Title: “I loved it!”
Reviews.Author: queotic
Reviews.Content: I planned a surprise vacation for my parents 30th anniversary and used a co worker's time share Getaway to book Tahiti Village. The rate for the 1 bedroom suite (Bora Bora) for 8 days, 7 seven nights was fantastic. The suite was so beautiful and spacious that my siblings and I moved from our hotel on the strip to their living room (every parent's worst nightmare lol.) The kitchen comes with 6 bowls, 6 plates, 6 spoons etc, so it's great for a small family/group. The garbage disposal and dishwasher are definately a plus, as is the washer/dry combo. The steam shower is big enough to have a small seat and the whirlpool is bigger than it appears in the photos. the bathroom had two entrances (bedroom and kitchen), so guests in the living room don't have to walk through the bedroom to access it. the bedroom is a nice size with a king (possibly queen) sized bed, full length mirrors and a 42 inch TV (always a plus lol). the couch in the living room is a sofa-bed that can fit two comfortably & there are extra pillows and blankets in the bedroom closet. there's also a dining table with 4 chairs and 3 stools at the bar. the patio is bigger than it looks in the picture and had a great view of the pool. (the suites on the outside of the hotel had either Strip or mountain views). the hotel is close to the airport , so occassionally, you'll hear planes passing by, but usually, the sound of the waterfalls next to the pool drowns that out. there's a convienence store called the wiki wiki which has the usual travel essentials (including water toys for the pool). we didn't go to tahiti joe's, but the on-site dennys was good and had an extremely nice waitress (rebecca, i believe). there is construction going on, but i think it stops pretty early because i've never seen it when i went to the pool in the mornings. tahiti village is a developing timeshare resort ($63,000 for a 2 bedroom unit? no thank you), so like other reviewers said, there are a lot of salesmen with potential buyers around, but most of them just smiled at the hotel guests, said good morning and held open the doors for us. we didn't rent a car, so parking wasn't a problem. the shuttles came every 30 minutes (on the hour and half hour). it took exactly half an hour from tahiti village to the last stop - about 12 minutes to the tropicana, another 13 to the second stop (i believe it was treasure island) and 5 more to the rivieria). the shuttles had a cooler full of complementary bottles of water - definately a nice touch when you're in the middle of the desert lol. the shuttles don't take the scenic route (straight up las vegas blvd), so they're able to skip the notorious strip traffic. tahiti village is on las vegas blvd, but it's about 2 miles south from the last major casino, mandalay bay, so it doesn't have the easy access to gambling the way strip hotels do. if gambling isn't your #1 priority though, then either using shuttles or renting a car is fine (strip casinos have free parking). the pool was FANTASTIC. whether it was noon or 9pm, the water always felt good. towels and water toys were provided (noodles, buckets, goggles, water volleyball). there was a cute little section with sand where children were usually playing. there was a volleyball net and several lifeguard stations (depending on the time of day, i saw one to three lifeguards). a previous poster mentioned not liking the gates to the pool. i didn't mind because 1) i carried my key whenever i left my room, so it wasn't an extra burden and 2), it made me feel more secure knowing that a stranger couldn't just walk into the pool area. there was a bbq pit behind the waterfalls with about 5 stations, but it was just TOO HOT for BBQing. the las vegas outlet center is right across the street and the stores had pretty good prices. this site has a listing of the stores: [--] the only other place that is close to TV is the Little Church of the West (the oldest chapel in Vegas). My parents renewed their vows there, so it was perfect for my family. the resort will hold your luggage for 24 hours after you check out (a bit early at 10am). this came in very handy since we had a midnight departure flight. my parents went to the time share presentation (2 hours), politely told them no thank you and received the usual timeshare gifts - casino credit ($100), 3 tickets to comedy shows, a japense show called mazuri (spelling?) and credit at a restaurant for lunch or dinner. there was a choice between those gifts or paying $20 for one of the cirque shows (zumanity at new york new york). TV has a red rock canyon tour for $2 and that was very nice. they also give hoover dam tours, but we found a cheaper price somewhere else, so i recommend looking around online first. all in all, we had a great time and would highly recommend tahiti village.

HotelInfo.Name: Tahiti Village
HotelInfo.Address: 7200 Las Vegas Blvd. S, Las Vegas, NV 89119
